Context: The Marketing Management – Financial Services Program at George Brown College aims to help students develop marketing skills for the financial services sector in Canada and globally. Students will learn how to apply marketing concepts and principles, create strategic marketing plans, and use industry-standard software for data analysis. This program is part of the School of Marketing and requires a one-semester work experience (either co-op or internship) for graduation. George Brown works with employers and industry partners to provide work experience opportunities. Students can also pursue self-directed industry work experiences. Tuition fees include membership to the Canadian Marketing Association (CMA) and IAB. The program combines courses on database marketing and prepares students for writing the Canadian Securities Course exams from the Canadian Securities Institute. To qualify for any designations/certifications, students must follow the process listed on their respective websites and meet the requirements applicable to them. The requirements for each designation/certification are set by the granting body, not George Brown College.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Marketing Management – Financial Services Program (Postgraduate) B406 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: The IAB (Interactive Advertising Bureau) membership includes student volunteer opportunities, members only webinars and podcasts, original Canadian digital marketing research, globally accepted digital ad standards, and globally standardized courses, certification, and custom workshops. Graduates from the program may find employment as marketing specialists, credit or business analysts, financial services officers, customer service representatives, personal banking representatives, and in various roles within the financial services industry. Toronto is the leading Canadian financial services centre with over 210,000 people working in the sector and the second-largest North American financial hub after New York City. To graduate, students need to complete 13 mandatory courses and one work experience term. The required courses for the first semester are COMP 1192 - Computer Applications for Database Marketing and FIN 4024 - Canadian Investments I, along with MARK 1027 (not shown in the text).
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Marketing Management – Financial Services Program (Postgraduate) B406 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Program Learning Outcomes:
- The graduate demonstrates the ability to formulate a marketing plan that will meet the needs or goals of a business or organization.
- The graduate can develop an integrated marketing communications plan for a product, concept, good and/or service based on an identified market need or target.
- The graduate can formulate strategies for developing new and/or modified products, concepts, goods and services that respond to evolving market needs.
- The graduate can develop strategies for the efficient and effective placement/distribution of products, concepts, goods and services that respond to evolving markets.
- The graduate can evaluate the impact of using different marketing strategies for a product, concept, good and/or service on the finances, Return on Investment (ROI) and business goals of an organization.
- The graduate can conduct market research to provide information needed to make marketing decisions.
- The graduate can communicate marketing information persuasively and accurately in oral, written, graphic and interactive media formats.
- The graduate can plan, prepare and deliver a sales presentation or pitch that addresses the needs of the client.
- The graduate can develop strategies with clients, customers, consumers and others to grow and maintain relationships.
- The graduate can develop learning and development strategies and plans to enhance professional growth in the field.
- The graduate can apply entrepreneurial strategies to identify and respond to new career opportunities that might include contract employment, and self-employment initiatives.

Courses:
1. FIN 4024 - Canadian Investments I
2. FIN 4025 - Canadian Investments II
3. MARK 1027 - Marketing Management
4. MARK 1031 - Principles of Marketing Financial Services
5. MARK 2037 - Database Marketing Strategies
6. MARK 4005 - Applied Business Communications
7. MARK 4012 - Marketing Metrics
8. MARK 4013 - Customer Experience
9. MARK 4031 - Marketing Management-Financial Management Seminar Series
10. BUS 4000 - Work Experience Prep Course
11. COOP 4002 / INTN 4002 / BAWT 4002 - Work Experience Term
12. MARK 1109 - Data Analytics & Data Mining
13. MARK 2044 - Principles of Marketing Research

Semester: 2

Context:
The college offers various employment initiatives including contract employment and self-employment. Participants are required to adhere to organizational policies and practices, apply business ethics and corporate social responsibility principles, and employ marketing techniques in response to business needs. The tuition fees for the domestic and international students are $4,313.00 and $17,774.00 respectively for the first two semesters starting in Fall 2022. Fees are subject to change for later program starts. International students should refer to the International Fees and Related Costs page for additional information. Financial assistance is available through OSAP for eligible applicants. Admission requirements include a college advanced diploma, bachelor's degree or relevant work experience with a resume and references. Applicants with international transcripts without English proficiency test results must take the George Brown College English assessment. Some college and university credits may qualify for exemptions.

FACTUAL INFORMATION:
- Employment initiatives: contract employment, self-employment
- Participate in organizational policies and practices
- Apply business ethics and corporate social responsibility principles
- Employ marketing techniques
- Tuition fees: domestic - $4,313.00, international - $17,774.00
- Financial assistance available through OSAP
- Admission requirements: college advanced diploma, bachelor's degree, relevant work experience, resume and references
- English proficiency test required for international applicants without results
- Some college and university credits may qualify for exemptions
